entry.title: Look to Austria for wines to try this summer
entry.summary:
Wherever you go in the country, it's hard to overstate Austrians' passion for wine. Known for its aromatic whites, Austria also has outstanding sweet wines, reds and field blends, all best enjoyed in a rural tavern.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
I first came across Austrian wine around 30 years ago in San Francisco, of all places, at a restaurant called The Slanted Door that served Vietnamese food, with which I was equally unfamiliar. I was blown away by a fresh, peppery white called grÃ¼ner veltliner â€” a wine made from a grape of the same name â€” along with how well it suited the dishes weâ€™d ordered.
Since then, itâ€™s become hugely popular. Almost every supermarket has an own-label grÃ¼ner and itâ€™s still my go-to with most Southeast Asiaâ€¦

entry.title: The science behind why Black Sabbathâ€™s music sounded â€˜satanicâ€™
entry.summary:
The idea that two simple notesâ€”not a song, just tonesâ€”could be â€œbannedâ€œ may seem ludicrous. But thatâ€™s the legend behind the crushing opening riff of Black Sabbathâ€™s 1970 debut. With just three ominous notes, guitarist Tony Iommi, alongside the anguished vocals of the late Ozzy Osbourne, unleashed a sound so unsettling it was said to have been forbidden for centuries.â€œThose notes were banned many years ago,â€ Iommi told the BBC in 2014. â€œItâ€™s supposed to have been a satanic thing.â€
While rock legend has never been the most reliable (see: Ozzy and the bat), this one does have a whisper of truth. Black Sabbath recruited what music theorists refer to as the â€˜tritone,â€™ â€”a dissonant interval once avoided by medieval choirs and now known in music lore as the â€œdevilâ€™s interval.â€ Also referredâ€¦

entry.title: Pollution, melting microbes, undamming rivers, risks for elders: 4 key climate issues
entry.summary: In a world increasingly shaped by climate extremes, environmental experts are delivering a blunt warning: four rapidly emerging threats could reshape life for millions unless urgent action is taken.

entry.title: Who were the Neanderthalsâ€”and why did they go extinct?
entry.summary:
This reconstruction of a female Neanderthal was made using ancient DNA evidence. Our ancient ancestors looked similar to modern humans but with more prominent brows and big teeth and eyes. Scientists believe they were also smarter than originally believed. Neanderthals were a hardy species, but these ancient human relatives disappeared 40,000 years ago. Hereâ€™s what scientists know.

  Neanderthals were our closest known relatives and walked the Earth between at least 400,000 and 40,000 years ago. But since their fossilized bones were discovered more than 160 years ago, there are still many questions about what they were like. The bones were uncovered by limestone quarry workers digging in Germanyâ€™s Neander Valley in 1856. At first, they thought theyâ€™d uncovered the â€¦

entry.title: The picturesque Spanish villages that tourists haven't foundâ€”yet
entry.summary:
Slightly up north of Madrid and Barcelona, nestling at the foothills of the Pyrenees, lies the region of Aragon, rich in history and natural beauty. Here, green hills hug the soaring mountains and dense forests open up to flowering meadows. Down in the valleys, ancient castles hide among the olive groves, endless vineyards disappear into the horizon and centuries-old villages bask in the Mediterranean sun all summer long.
Aragonâ€™s historical claim to fame reaches all the way to America. Known as the Kingdom of Aragon in the 11th century, it became a precursor to the modern-day Spain, when King Ferdinand of Aragon married Queen Isabella of Castile in 1469. About two decades later, the royal couple financed Christopher Columbusâ€™s voyage to the New World.Â
In recent years, beautifulâ€¦

entry.title: The UK's nightlife has lost its mojoâ€”can it be saved?
entry.summary:
With tickets to club nights costing up to Â£50 and pints averaging over Â£5, many can't afford to go out any more. Venues are in crisis, with more closures than ever â€” but superclubs, sober parties and new government powers could save the after-dark music scene.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Nights out have been a staple of British life since the early 20th century, when the countryâ€™s first nightclubs opened. But in recent years, the country has seen a surge in venue closures, with a study by the Night Time Industries Association (NTIA) suggesting that there could be no nightclubs by 2030. With a clutch of big openings and a new government taskforce, there are reasons to remain hopeful â€” but are we witnessing the end of nightlife as we know iâ€¦

entry.title: 20 years after Katrina, New Orleanians are redefining 'home'
entry.summary:
Shelton Alexander is one of hundred of thousands of New Orleans residents who survived the devastation of Hurricane Katrina in 2005. After one of the deadliest hurricanes in American history, many New Orleans residents faced a mountain of obstacles to rebuild. These are their stories.
On August 28, 2005, the eve of Hurricane Katrinaâ€™s landfall, Shelton Alexander stood outside his home in St. Bernard Parish, a neighborhood in New Orleans, as a storm warning echoed from a nearby radio. Katrina was gaining strength by the hour.
At that point, the poet and former Marine made sure his mother evacuated. But for himself, staying felt like the only optionâ€”a mix of necessity, responsibility, and quiet defiance in the face of a storm he knew would be unlike anything heâ€™d seen before. â€¦

entry.title: What was it like to live in Old Babylon?
entry.summary:
The city of Babylon, flanking the Euphrates River in Lower Mesopotamia, reached the zenith of its early age during the reign of King Hammurabi (r.1792-1750 B.C.). Under his rule, the capital of the Babylonian empire was consolidated as a cosmopolitan hub, attracting migrants from across the region. The Empire as a whole had been gaining power and prestige during the Old Babylonian Empire (1894â€“1595 B.C.), but Hammurabi went on to take over large swaths of territory in Mesopotamia, conquering far flung cities such as Ur, Eshnunna, Assur, Nineveh, and Tuttul. As Hammurabiâ€™s reach extended, much of the kingdom flourishedâ€”culturally, economically, socially, and in religionâ€” especially in the capital, Babylon.
The thousands of cuneiform texts that survive from this time provide fasciâ€¦

entry.title: How one shipwreck and a cargo of lost gold sparked a U.S. financial panic
entry.summary: When the Central America sank, it became the worst maritime disaster in Americaâ€™s history. The loss of the gold shipment in the hold contributed to a nationwide economic crisis. The S.S. Central America sank off the coast of South Carolina in 1857, taking with it 425 lives and a fortune in gold rush bounty. As the sun slipped below the horizon on the evening of September 8, 1857, a festive atmosphere prevailed in the first-class dining room aboard the S.S. Central America. The side-wheel paddle steamer had left Havana that morning under fair skies and was making its way to New York City on the second and final leg of a voyage that had begun five days earlier in Panama. Aboard were 477 passengers and a crew of 101. Seated at the captainâ€™s table that night was a newlyâ€¦

entry.title: 7 of the best book festivals around the world
entry.summary:
A woman poses for a photo at the Calabash International Literary Festival in Treasure Beach, Jamaica. The family-owned Jakeâ€™s Hotel hosts the annual festival. From Jamaica to Jaipur, these literary festivals celebrate the power of the written word and offer you a chance to hear from celebrated and up-and-coming authorsâ€”as well as fellow bibliophiles.
The ritual of convening around books is a worldwide traditionâ€”from the small fishing village of Treasure Beach in Jamaica to a countryside street in Wales. To pore over a new book in a new setting with like-minded people garners community and inspiration. Add in a gorgeous setting, riveting speakers, and some of the worldâ€™s best restaurants and hotels nearby, and book festivals can serve as a starting point for a greater travel adventuâ€¦

entry.title: Cosmic radiation gave the Fantastic Four superpowers. Here's what would happen in real life.
entry.summary:
When we gaze up at the night sky, we often marvel at the twinkling stars, distant planets, and expansive galaxies. Yet, beyond the visible spectrum lies a more mysterious aspect of the cosmosâ€”cosmic radiation.
These are high energy particles that stream through the universe at nearly the speed of light, according to Dimitra Atri of the Mars Research Group at New York University Abu Dhabi's Center for Astrophysics and Space Science. They originate from events like supernova explosions and solar flares and travel through space, constantly bombarding Earth in all directions and entering its atmosphere.
(How cosmic rays helped find a tunnel in Egypt's Great Pyramid.)
In Marvel Studiosâ€™ The Fantastic Four: First Steps, now playing only in theaters, the Fantastic 4 receive their pâ€¦

entry.title: The women in Carl Jungâ€™s shadow
entry.summary:
For two generations, Emma Jungâ€”the wife of the famous Swiss psychoanalyst Carl Jungâ€”was remembered inside her family mostly as a beloved mother and grandmother. Her original work documenting the deep and rigorous exploration of her own unconscious simply wasnâ€™t discussed.
â€œNo one was any longer aware of what she actually produced,â€ says Thomas Fischer, great-grandson of Carl and Emmaâ€”and the former director of the Foundation of the Works of C.G. Jungâ€”who currently serves as a board member and the editor for the foundation.
Now, 150 years after Carl Jungâ€™s birth, Emma and several of his other female collaborators are finally stepping into the spotlight and being recognized as brilliant thinkers of their own who helped shape some of Jungâ€™s most famous theories, including individuatâ€¦

entry.title: UN urges restraint as Thailand-Cambodia clashes displace thousands; Security Council meets
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General has urged â€œutmost restraintâ€ amid intensifying border clashes between Thailand and Cambodia as the Security Council met behind closed doors on Friday to address the most serious escalation between the two Southeast Asian neighbours in more than a decade.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Syria: Deadly sectarian violence displaces thousands in Sweida; healthcare attacked
entry.summary: As deadly sectarian violence continues to displace hundreds of thousands of civilians in Syriaâ€™s Sweida Governorate, the World Health Organization (WHO) confirmed on Friday that attacks on health facilities had killed two doctors.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: More deaths reported as starvation spreads
entry.summary: The UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) has again sounded the alarm over the catastrophic and rapidly deteriorating conditions in the Gaza Strip as Israeli military operations continue to cause death, displacement and destruction.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza First Person: â€˜The best of humankind in a place abandoned by humanityâ€™
entry.summary: In the centre of war-torn Gaza, UN staff continue to work despite the â€œunprecedentedâ€ destruction and suffering around them, according to the UN Childrenâ€™s Fund (UNICEF) Head of Office.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN warns of escalating human toll in Ukraine amid relentless aerial attacks, mounting aid shortfall
entry.summary: Russian aerial attacks continue to intensify across Ukraine, exacting a rising toll on civilians and infrastructure, senior UN officials told the Security Council on Friday, warning of mounting humanitarian needs amid faltering donor support.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: In hard-hitting human rights address, Guterres calls for urgent action on Gaza, authoritarianism and climate justice
entry.summary: The world is facing a â€œmoral crisisâ€ marked by rising authoritarianism, deepening inequality and a dangerous indifference to human suffering, UN Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres warns in a powerful address on human rights.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: 1.3 million Sudanese return home, offering fragile hope for recovery
entry.summary: With pockets of relative safety emerging in Sudan, over 1.3 million Sudanese people, including one million who were internally displaced and over 300,000 refugees, have returned home, according to UN agencies.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: SECURITY COUNCIL LIVE: Situation in Ukraine
entry.summary: The UN Security Council is meeting on Friday morning to discuss the situation in Ukraine amid mounting concerns over the intensifying hostilities and growing humanitarian needs. Senior UN political affairs and humanitarian officials are expected to brief the Council. Follow our live coverage from UN News, in coordination with UN Meetings Coverage, for updates from the chamber. UN News App users can follow here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Women and girls of African descent: Celebrating contributions, recognising challenges
entry.summary: This Friday marks the first observation of the International Day of Women and Girls of African Descent, following a declaration last year by the UN General Assembly.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Forest bathing is the secret to feel-good travel
entry.summary:
Bluebells bloom across a small forest in Shaftesbury, Dorset, United Kingdom. Studies show that forest bathing in woodlands such as this can boost physical and mental health. These five destinations maximize the health benefits of the Japanese art of forest bathing.
Forest bathing emerged in Japan in the 1980s as a physiological and psychological exercise called shinrin-yoku, meaning â€œforest bathingâ€ or â€œtaking in the forest atmosphere.â€ Now this type of walking is a fitness trend and a mindfulness practice for better mental health.
The original purpose was two-fold: to offer an antidote to tech-boom burnout and inspire people to reconnect with and protect the countryâ€™s forests.
The Japanese quickly embraced this form of â€œecotherapy.â€ In the 1990s, researchers began studyâ€¦

entry.title: Why you should visit these 5 European lakes
entry.summary:
These five European lakes are worthy of your attention this summer. From tri-country bike rides around Germanyâ€™s Lake Constance to swims in the shadow of towering mountains in Sloveniaâ€™s Lake Bohinj, Europeâ€™s lakes are so lovely in summer that you wonâ€™t miss the sea for a minute. Packing in history, culture, food, beaches, alley-woven villages and big wilderness, here are five favourites to get you started.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
As the summer heat rises along the coast of the Med, turn your gaze instead to Europeâ€™s dazzlingly diverse array of lakes. Beyond swimming, kayaking and standup paddleboarding in crystal-clear waters, thereâ€™s plenty to explore â€” think medieval castles and vineyards, prehistoric pile dwellings and Byzantine mâ€¦

entry.title: Will psychedelics ever live up to their hype?
Are we alone? Earthâ€™s giant new telescope could finally tell us.
How Louis Braille revolutionized a writing system
entry.summary:
Where would we be without writing? From its origins over 5,000 years ago in ancient Mesopotamia, the history of writing echoes the history of humanity. The Greeks and Romans developed unique alphabets, the Chinese evolved complex characters, and today we read novels, newspapers, and social media. A bedrock of human civilization, writing is fundamental for the rule of law and the accumulation of knowledge and culture. Yet it was not until the 19th century that blind people had access to writing.
Between 1824 and 1825, Louis Braille created a system of raised dot letters that could be read with the hands. Initially ignored, his invention would be universally adopted by the 20th century, opening a new world of learning for the visually impaired. In a speech at the Sorbonne on the centennâ€¦

entry.title: This city offers a stunning respite from Veniceâ€™s crowds
entry.summary:
About 40 miles from Veniceâ€™s winding waterways and busy plazas lies Vicenza, an elegant Renaissance jewel. To visit Vicenza is to breathe in the genius of one of historyâ€™s most influential architects, Andrea Palladio.
Though born in nearby Padua, this 16th century architect made his study of classical Greek and Roman architecture central to the design style that later reached throughout Europe and across the Atlanticâ€”a style that inspired Thomas Jefferson to design Monticello after Palladian ideals.
Come for the architecture, but stay to explore a rich tapestry of history and gastronomy. From its museums full of fine art to its stately villas, Vicenza is worth the day trip from Venetoâ€™s more crowded destinations. Â Â
Piazza dei Signori is a beautiful starting point. Itâ€™s heâ€¦

entry.title: Is it possible to take too much melatonin?
entry.summary:
If youâ€™ve ever taken a melatonin supplement as a last-ditch attempt to save your sleep, youâ€™re in good company: Research suggests people in the U.S. have steadily reached for more melatonin over the past couple of decades, and an American Academy of Sleep Medicine (AASM) survey estimates that roughly two-thirds of U.S. adults have used some form of melatonin to help them drift off.Â
The appeal is undeniable: Your brain naturally makes this hormone to regulate your sleep-wake cycle. The synthetic form of melatonin usually found in supplements is a relatively low-risk substance for adults, plus itâ€™s available over the counter. Package this into a trendy bottle brimming with colorful gummies (with plenty of endorsements from â€œwellnessâ€ influencers), and youâ€™re giving the chronically exhaâ€¦

entry.title: Two ex-militia leaders in Central African Republic sentenced for war crimes, crimes against humanity
entry.summary: Two former leaders of the predominantly Christian Anti-Balaka militia in the Central African Republic have been convicted of multiple war crimes and crimes against humanity by the International Criminal Court (ICC).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Thailand-Cambodia border hostilities, humanitarian efforts in Syria and attacks across Ukraine
entry.summary: In a dramatic escalation of a long-standing border dispute, a deadly exchange of fire between Thailand and Cambodia killed at least 11 civilians and a soldier on Thursday, according to news reports. Both states are claiming the other side fired first.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜The UN is here to do the right thingsâ€™: Envoy Colin Stewart bids farewell but keeps the faith
entry.summary: After nearly three decades on the frontlines of UNâ€™s peace operations â€“ from Timor-Lesteâ€™s turbulent independence referendum to Western Saharaâ€™s protracted ceasefire and Cyprusâ€™ frozen conflict â€“ Colin Stewart is leaving the Organization with his faith in it intact.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN forum affirms stronger commitment to achieve sustainable development
entry.summary: The High-Level Political Forum on Sustainable Development (HLPF) has concluded at United Nations Headquarters in New York following a week-and-a-half of substantive discussion between Member States, civil society representatives and UN agencies.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜Famine silently begins to unfoldâ€™ in Gaza, UNRWA chief says
entry.summary: â€œPeople in Gaza are neither dead nor alive, they are walking corpses.â€

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Global collaboration grows to address crises in Gaza, Sudan, Afghanistan
entry.summary: Amid growing geopolitical turbulence, the United Nations is deepening its collaboration with the Organization of Islamic Cooperation (OIC) to help address some of the worldâ€™s most complex and protracted conflicts, from Gaza and Sudan to Myanmar and Afghanistan.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Torture, threats and arbitrary arrests: UN warns of â€˜serious abusesâ€™ against Afghans forced to return
entry.summary: Afghans returning to their country face â€œserious violationsâ€ of their human rights committed by the Taliban de facto authorities, according to a United Nations report published on Thursday amid mass deportation campaigns from Iran and Pakistan.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Deep-sea must not turn into â€˜Wild Westâ€™ of rare minerals exploitation, agency head says
entry.summary: Nations are pursuing underwater exploration for highly sought-after rare earth minerals, but the head of the UNâ€™s International Seabed Authority (ISA) said the deep-sea belongs to no single country or corporation as efforts are underway to ensure this rich resource will not become â€œthe Wild Westâ€ of exploitation.

entry.title: Who was Mary Magdalene?
entry.summary:
Mary Magdalene is one of the most recognized figures in the Bible. She has been called a woman possessed by demons, a sex worker, and the wife of Jesus.
Her story has been written and rewritten countless times in the 2,000 years since she was a follower of Jesus of Nazareth, yet so much about Mary Magdalene remains shrouded in mystery. She is sometimes confused with Mary of Bethany, another biblical figure, and thought to have written a Gospel. There are questions about her real name, when and where she was born, and how Mary Magdalene died.
What is true about herâ€”and what archaeological evidence do scholars have about her life and world?
Textual evidence about Mary Magdalene largely comes from the canonical Gospels credited to Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John. They identify â€¦

entry.title: Forget about 10,000 steps a dayâ€”science now has a more accurate number
entry.summary:
An explorer walks across sand dunes on Socotra, Yemen, 2018. Getting 10,000 steps in every day can be challenging, and a new study suggests 7,000 steps can reduce the risk of developing common but serious health conditions. Walking more is associated with reduced risk for dementia, diabetes, heart disease, and moreâ€”but a new study says you can get fewer than 10,000 steps a day and still see all those benefits.
If youâ€™ve been told that walking 10,000 steps a day is mandatory for good health, you might be surprised to learn that scientists suspect the figure was created to market pedometers and wasn't based on actual data. The number of steps that stave off numerous chronic conditions is actually much lower, according to a paper published today in Lancet Public Health that reviewed tâ€¦

entry.title: Different dino species traveled togetherâ€”like the movies
entry.summary:
A herd of ceratopsians (Styracosaurus albertensis) accompanied by an ankylosaur (Euplocephalus tutus) walk through an old river channel under the watchful eyes of two tyrannosaurs (Gorgosaurus libratus). A newly discovered trove of fossilized footprints provides what may be the first evidence of prehistoric diversity in dinosaur herds, though not everyone is convinced.
Across the African savanna, zebras and wildebeests travel together in massive herds often peppered with impalas and gazelles. The larger the herd, the safer its members are from predators like lions, hyenas and African wild dogs.
Scientists have wondered whether dinosaurs similarly engaged in mixed-species herding behavior. Childrenâ€™s movies like â€œThe Land Before Timeâ€ series and â€œDinosaurâ€ (2000) often depict mâ€¦

entry.title: Is it a bird? A monkey? No, it's a new prehistoric reptile
entry.summary: Reconstruction and illustration of Mirasaura in itâ€™s natural forested environment Mirasaura grauvogeli had a featherlike crest and a tail like a monkey. â€œIt's been a long time since I've been so blown away by a new fossil discovery.â€ Some 247 million years ago, a bizarre, six-inch-long reptile crept down a branch, its prehensile tail and feet clutching the bark like a monkey, and its narrow, birdlike face scanning its surroundings. On its back, an overlapping fan of stiff structures likely caught the light, vibrant with color. They looked very much like feathers, but were something entirely different as the reptile wasnâ€™t related to birds or dinosaurs, and it existed a hundred million years before the first dinosaur took wing.Â  Researchers have long believed things likeâ€¦

entry.title: How Pew Research Center Uses Its National Public Opinion Reference Survey (NPORS)
entry.summary: In 2020, Pew Research Center launched a new project called the National Public Opinion Reference Survey (NPORS). NPORS is an annual, cross-sectional survey of U.S. adults. Respondents can answer either by paper or online, and they are selected using address-based sampling from the United States Postal Serviceâ€™s computerized delivery sequence file. The post How Pew Research Center Uses Its National Public Opinion Reference Survey (NPORS) appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 10 historicâ€”and sometimes hauntedâ€”hotels in Colorado
entry.summary:
The Brown Palace Hotel was the passion project of Henry Brown, the real estate developer who donated land to create Denver's state capitol building. Ghost stories, swinging saloon doors, and old-world glamourâ€”these hotels offer more character than your average accommodation.
Colorado may be a beloved outdoor recreation destination, but it has more to offer than ski slopes and hiking trails. Once home to miners and cowboys, the Centennial State was a key player not only in the development of the American West but also in establishing Wild West culture. Whether deep in the Rocky Mountains or amid the urban sprawl of Denver, stay in historical hotels to experience this culture for yourself. These properties function as living museums, with antiques, ghosts, and Victorian architecture â€¦

entry.title: Childbirth is still too dangerous. This ancient profession can help.
entry.summary:
A midwife holds a newborn in TzajalchÃ©n, Mexico, 2021. Midwives are making a big comeback, and solving a crisis in maternal health care.
Itâ€™s 5 a.m. at Mother Health International (MHI), a birth center in Northern Uganda affiliated with Yale University, when the call comes in from a local midwife about 12 miles away. A woman in her village has gone into labor. The alert sets a series of gears into motion: a motorcycle driver is immediately dispatched to zip down the mostly unpaved roads to her location, while the nurse midwives at MHI prepare a room for labor and delivery. Within an hour, the laboring mother and her local midwife arrive at MHI where sheâ€™s greeted by nurse midwives who work together to ensure a safe delivery. An ambulance stands ready in case the birth becomes diffâ€¦

entry.title: This one-minute workout could transform your health
entry.summary:
Social media hypes sprinting as a quick fixâ€”but research shows short bursts of high-intensity running can improve VOâ‚‚ max, preserve fast-twitch muscle fibers, and support brain and bone health with minimal time investment. Influencers call sprinting the ultimate fat-burning workout. Experts say itâ€™s more nuancedâ€”but research shows this high-intensity exercise offers surprising benefits for the heart, muscles, and even the brain.
Sprinting has been getting a lot of hype online. But the research backs it up: short, intense bursts of running offer powerful benefitsâ€”from cardiovascular fitness to strength and cognitive function. And you donâ€™t have to do it every day to see results.
Because itâ€™s high-impact, sprinting isnâ€™t right for everyone. But for those without physical limitatâ€¦

entry.title: 8 state parks that deliver the awe without the crowds
entry.summary:
Under the Milky Way Galaxy, a night explorer stands at the entrance to Moon Caves in Nevada's Cathedral Gorge State Park. Less famous but just as unforgettable, these state parks showcase iconic landscapes without the long lines at Americaâ€™s national parks.
As popular national parks grapple withÂ another record-breaking yearÂ of crowds, state-managed public lands offer a less-explored option. While a few parks, like Niagara Falls, with 9 million annual visitors, still contend with crowds, most feel almost deserted. If long lines and packed parking lots have you rethinking your travel plans to some of the busiest national parks, consider one of these eight state park alternatives that deliver the awe without the crowds.Â
With prolific biodiversity within just a dayâ€™s drive of oâ€¦

entry.title: â€˜Corn sweatâ€™â€”and other weird weather phenomenaâ€”explained
entry.summary:
On a hot day, fields of corn transpiring water, also known as "corn sweat", can raise local humidity levels by 30 to 40 percent. The Midwestâ€™s massive corn fields are making the region more humid as it battles a sweltering heatwave.
As the U.S. Midwest swelters under the effects of yet another heatwave, temperatures and humidity in the region are being further fueled by â€œsweatingâ€ corn. If you didnâ€™t have sweaty produce on your 2025 bingo card, youâ€™re not alone; but â€œcorn sweatâ€ is a real phenomenon, well known to meteorologists and farmers alike, that adds moisture to the atmosphere and makes hot conditions even hotter and more unpleasant.
Itâ€™s just one unexpected way in which human activities, from agriculture to deforestation and pollution, can have surprising effects on râ€¦

entry.title: Is it a bird? A monkey? No, it's a new prehistoric reptile
entry.summary: Reconstruction and illustration of Mirasaura in itâ€™s natural forested environment Mirasaura grauvogeli had a featherlike crest and a tail like a monkey. â€œIt's been a long time since I've been so blown away by a new fossil discovery.â€ Some 247 million years ago, a bizarre, six-inch-long reptile crept down a branch, its prehensile tail and feet clutching the bark like a monkey, and its narrow, birdlike face scanning its surroundings. On its back, an overlapping fan of stiff structures likely caught the light, vibrant with color. They looked very much like feathers, but were something entirely different as the reptile wasnâ€™t related to birds or dinosaurs, and it existed a hundred million years before the first dinosaur took wing.Â  Researchers have long believed things likeâ€¦

entry.title: Syria: Second convoy brings critical aid to Sweida
entry.summary: A second convoy from the Syrian Arab Red Crescent (SARC) reached battered Sweida on Wednesday, the UN Office for the Coordinatin of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) reported in its latest update.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Haiti: Violence and displacement driving humanitarian crisis as funding needs go unmet
entry.summary: Escalating gang violence and displacement continue to drive humanitarian needs in Haiti, the UN said on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Nigeria: Amid record hunger and surging insecurity, emergency food assistance to stall entirely
entry.summary: At a time of escalating violence and record levels of hunger in Nigeria, critical funding shortfalls are forcing the UN World Food Program (WFP) to suspend all emergency food and nutrition aid for 1.3 million people in the northeast of the country.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Home is where the heart is â€” and where development begins
entry.summary: When Denis Jobin, a senior evaluation specialist at the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), visited a slum in Kenya in March as part of an ongoing evaluation, the smell was overwhelming.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World Court says countries are legally obligated to curb emissions, protect climate
entry.summary: The International Court of Justice (ICJ) in the Hague, Netherlands, issued its advisory opinion on the obligations of states in respect of climate change, read out by the President of the Court, Judge Iwasawa Yuji, on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN official reiterates call for Gaza ceasefire as â€˜nightmare of historic proportionsâ€™ unfolds
entry.summary: A senior UN official on Wednesday urged the Security Council to push for an immediate ceasefire in Gaza and the release of all hostages, warning that the war has become â€œa nightmare of historic proportionsâ€ and it is â€œlong past timeâ€ for the fighting to end and for hostages to return home.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜Catastrophic birth outcomesâ€™ in Gaza threaten a whole generation, warns UN agency
entry.summary: Pregnant women and newborns in Gaza face â€œcatastrophicâ€ conditions, including a dysfunctional healthcare system, psychological stress and food deprivation the UN reproductive health agency (UNFPA) reported on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: SECURITY COUNCIL LIVE: Debate on the situation in the Middle East
entry.summary: The Security Council meets today for its quarterly open debate on the situation in the Middle East, with a focus on the worsening crisis in Gaza. UN Assistant Secretary-General Khaled Khiari is expected to brief on the situation in the war-ravaged enclave where food entry and distribution remain severely restricted, malnutrition is rising, and fuel and shelter supplies are critically scarce. UN News, in coordination with UN Meetings Coverage, brings you live updates from todayâ€™s discussions. UN News App users can follow here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Who was King Tut, the teen pharaoh who captivated the world?
entry.summary:
King Tut, or Tutankhamun, is one of the most famous rulers who ever lived thanks to the 1922 discovery of the pharaohâ€™s tomb in Egyptâ€™s Valley of the Kings. The find stirred the imaginations of millions who were fascinated by the boy kingâ€™s golden-masked mummy.
But what do we really know about King Tut? Although many details of his reign remain lost to time, historians have spent years trying to piece together the pharaohâ€™s life and legacy. Hereâ€™s what theyâ€™ve learnedâ€”and the biggest questions that remain.
Born during ancient Egyptâ€™s 18th Dynastyâ€”which stretched from 1550 B.C. to 1295 B.C.â€”Tut began his life under a different name: Tutankhaten.
In the years before Tut rose to the throne, Egypt was going through a period of great upheaval. King Amenhotep IV, who is believedâ€¦

entry.title: 8 of the best European national parks to discover this summer
entry.summary:
Mother Nature was at her most adventurous when she shaped mainland Franceâ€™s second-largest national park, the Massif des Ecrins. Fierce summer temperatures can make much of Southern Europe difficult for active, nature-loving breaks in summer. But that still leaves a dazzling array of national parks to explore in the Alps and the north. Here are eight of the best to consider for your next adventure.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Europeâ€™s national parks contain a magnificent array of landscapes; think glaciers, volcanoes, primeval forests, mountain ranges and wild Atlantic coasts. In many cases, summer is the best time to visit them. Here weâ€™ve picked out eight that show off the continentâ€™s diversity as well as its beauty.
These parks arâ€¦

entry.title: Medieval Murder Maps
entry.summary: Medieval Murder Maps is a project that maps and tells the stories ofâ€¦ Tags: homicide, medieval

entry.title: Diet soda might be making you hungrier
entry.summary:
Artificial sweeteners in diet sodas can potentially trigger brain activity linked to hunger, raising questions about their role in weight control. The idea that diet sodas can help you lose weight is becoming increasingly complicated as emerging research suggests they may confuse the brainâ€”and trigger an urge to eat.
Millions of people reach for diet sodas each day to reduce sugar intake, manage their weight, or make healthier choices. But new research suggests these artificially sweetened drinks may do more than satisfy a sweet toothâ€”they may also be quietly rewiring how the brain regulates hunger.
Artificial sweeteners have long been controversial for their possible link to cancer and poor gut health. Yet some studies suggest that sweeteners like sucralose may stimulate the â€¦

entry.title: How the province of Girona became one of Spain's gastronomy stars
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
High on a Catalan hilltop just beyond the city of Gironaâ€™s medieval old town, the maÃ®tre dâ€™ at the Roca brothersâ€™ newly opened restaurant, Esperit Roca, draws back a heavy curtain and ushers me into a cavernous, domed wine cellar.
Thereâ€™s a sense of theatre as the haunting aria from Handelâ€™s The Triumph of Time and Truth oratorio announces my arrival and Iâ€™m guided past a cityâ€™s worth of wine racks into a high-ceilinged, industrial-chic dining room thatâ€™s been stylishly converted from a 19th-century fortress.
Esperit Roca is the latest restaurant from chef Joan Roca and his brothers, sommelier Josep and pastry chef Jordi, whose three Michelin-starred El Celler de Can Roca has twice been awarded the number one â€¦

entry.title: The sirens in ancient mythology werenâ€™t the seductresses of today
entry.summary:
Sirens torment Ulysses with their enchanting song in Herbert James Draper's 1909 painting titled 'Ulysses and the Sirens.' Draper portrays the Sirens as sexualized mermaids, consistent with other Edwardian era depictions of the creatures. For thousands of years sirens have lured sailors, haunted coastlinesâ€”and shapeshifted through myth and media. Here's how they evolved to the seductive mermaids of our modern imagination.
The Greek hero Odysseus famously faces many travails as he attempts to return home following the Trojan War, from giant cannibals to enigmatic enchantresses. But one challenge stands out as perhaps the most evocative, dangerous, and enduring of them all: the sirens, with their hypnotic and mesmerizing song, who call to passing sailors. To stop is certain death.Â â€¦

entry.title: What causes Parkinson's disease? Scientists uncover a new clue.
entry.summary:
A computer illustration of human pegivirus, an RNA (ribonucleic acid) virus scientists believe may be linked to Parkinson's disease. A recent study linking human pegivirus to Parkinsonâ€™s is leading scientists to examine the connection between other viral infections and neurodegenerative diseases.
More thanÂ 10 million people worldwideÂ are living with Parkinsonâ€™s disease, a progressive neurodegenerative disorder that leads toÂ symptoms such as tremors, slow movement, limb stiffness, and balance issues. Scientists still donâ€™t know what causes the disease, but itâ€™s thought to develop due to a complex mixture of genetic and environmental factors, and treatment is still quite limited.Â
But new research is putting scientists one step closer to some possible answers.Â
In aÂ recent â€¦

entry.title: 4,000-year-old victim was shot in the backâ€”and survived
entry.summary:
Close-up of the flint arrowhead embedded in a human rib, found at the Roc de les Orenetes site (Queralbs, RipollÃ¨s). This rib bone discovered in a cave in the Spanish Pyrenees tells a story of Bronze Age violence. But who fired the shot?
A flint arrowhead lodged in a rib from a person who lived in the Spanish Pyrenees more than 4,000 years ago was most likely shot during a skirmish with a rival clan, researchers say.
"It is direct evidence of a violent conflict episode," says Carlos Tornero, who led the team that unearthed the rib in a mountain cave 6,000 feet above sea level near the Spanish-French border. His team announced the finding July 8.
Previous excavations at the caveâ€”called Roc de les Orenetes, or "Rock of the Swallows" in Catalanâ€”unearthed thousands of human bâ€¦

entry.title: Need a burnout break? Consider an all-inclusive resort.
entry.summary:
The all-inclusive concept has expanded and evolved to appeal to a wider demographic. Originally designed as a budget-friendly escape, the concept of the all-inclusive resort is gaining in popularity again as exhausted travelers look to indulge in the luxury of doing nothing.
A bucket of beers perspire next to my lounge chair. Turquoise water laps at the shore. A book I havenâ€™t had time to finish in six months is spread across my lap.Â Coconut shrimp are on the horizon, to be delivered any minute. Why had I resisted an all-inclusive getaway for so long?Â
Like many others, Iâ€™ve long thought of all-inclusive resorts as a cop-out approach to traveling, characterized by overcrowding and a party-centric, cookie-cutter feel. But reaching a state of total burnout in both life and travâ€¦

entry.title: Dig into Britainâ€™s ancient past at these 7 archaeological sites
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Despite their ancient age, the UK's most famous archaeological treasures keep revealing new secrets, from recently unearthed dinosaur species to new Roman excavations. To help you follow the archaeology buzz, we dig into the nationâ€™s top spots to explore our ancient past, where revamped museums, interactive exhibits and hands-on excavation experiences bring our early history vividly to life.
First unearthed in 1939, with the shadow of the Second World War looming, Sutton Hoo is an early medieval royal burial site thatâ€™s famously home to the ship burial of seventh-century Anglo-Saxon King RÃ¦dwald.
Long-neglected, Sutton Hoo reopened in summer 2019 after a year-long refurbishment, which included transformiâ€¦

entry.title: Security Council, in unanimous vote, presses nations to resolve disputes peacefully
entry.summary: The Security Council on Tuesday adopted a resolution urging all Member States to â€œutilize effectivelyâ€ the mechanisms for pacific settlement of disputes as outlined in the United Nations Charter, including â€œnegotiation, enquiry, mediation, conciliation, arbitration, judicial settlementâ€ and other peaceful means of their choice.

entry.summary: The chief economist of the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), MÃ¡ximo Torero Cullen, previewed its annual State of Food Security and Nutrition in the World (SOFI) report in a briefing on Tuesday to journalists at UN Headquarters in New York.

entry.title: Sudan: UN scales up response plan as humanitarian needs rise in Tawila
entry.summary: As the humanitarian crisis deepens in Sudan, the UN and partners have revised and scaled up a response plan to support more than 380,000 displaced people in Tawila, North Darfur state.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN laments US withdrawal from educational and cultural agency
entry.summary: The United States announced on Tuesday that it will leave the UN Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO), which will take effect at the end of December 2026.

entry.title: Deep dive into the International Seabed Authority: Why it matters now
entry.summary: Protecting underwater ecosystems from the growing interest in rare mineral mining, framing deep-sea laws and building a biobank are among landmark achievements of the UNâ€™s International Seabed Authority (ISA), which is marking its 30th anniversary at its Kingston, Jamaica, headquarters.

entry.title: â€˜Peace is a choiceâ€™: UN chief urges diplomacy as wars spread from Gaza to Ukraine
entry.summary: Warning that the world is failing to uphold international law as wars stretch from Gaza to Ukraine, UN Secretaryâ€‘General AntÃ³nio Guterres urged all nations to choose diplomacy over division and recommit to settling disputes peacefully.

entry.title: SECURITY COUNCIL LIVE: High-level debate on peaceful settlements of dispute
entry.summary: The UN Security Council meets today for a high-level open debate on Promoting International Peace and Security through Multilateralism and Peaceful Settlement of Disputes, chaired by Pakistanâ€™s Deputy Prime Minister and Foreign Minister Mohammad Ishaq Dar. UN Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres is expected to brief as over 80 Member States join discussions on strengthening diplomacy and mechanisms for conflict prevention. entry.title: UNâ€™s Guterres declares fossil fuel era fading; presses nations for new climate plans before COP30 summit
entry.summary: UN Secretaryâ€‘General AntÃ³nio Guterres declared the world has â€œpassed the point of no returnâ€ on the shift to renewables and implored governments to file sweeping new climate plans before Novemberâ€™s COP30 climate summit in Brazil, saying the fossil fuel era is nearing its end.

entry.title: Food lifeline fading for millions in South Sudan hit by conflict and climate shocks
entry.summary: South Sudanâ€™s dramatic hunger crisis is worsening and millions of people there could miss out on food aid because of the global humanitarian funding crisis, the UN World Food Programme (WFP) said on Tuesday.

entry.title: Gaza: UN staff now fainting from hunger, exhaustion; WHO worker detained
entry.summary: Worrying alerts from United Nations staff in the Gaza Strip who have been fainting from hunger and exhaustion over the past 48 hours have increased fears for peopleâ€™s survival in the devastated enclave, UN humanitarians said on Tuesday.

entry.title: Knowledge and justice
entry.summary: Any legal system that fails to compensate people for epistemic harm is unjust. Their damage must be named and remedied - by Mitch Woolery Read at Aeon

entry.title: Fighting for Accountability and Press Freedom in West Africa
entry.summary: For almost 30 years, the Media Foundation for West Africa has supported watchdog journalism and press freedom in both democratic and authoritarian states across the region.

entry.title: What is lightning?
entry.summary:
Lightning flashes during a tropical storm in Guatemala. Hereâ€™s everything you need to know about lightning, from how it forms to common myths and how to stay safe.
Lightning flashing across a darkened sky makes an unforgettable image. With their drama and power, itâ€™s no wonder people have infused them with symbolic meaning. Theyâ€™re associated with mythological deities, such as Zeus and Thor, and even an emoji, in popular culture.
In daily life, these electric currents can be dangerous, sparking intense forest fires and causing deaths. It doesnâ€™t help that there are many myths about lightning behavior.
From its causes to safety tips, hereâ€™s everything you need to know about these bolts from the blue.
Lightning is an electrical discharge caused by imbalances between â€¦

entry.title: This summer has seen the shortest days in Earthâ€™s recorded history
The race to save the first color photos
entry.summary:
First digitized in 2008 (left), this 1937 photo of a dance performance in Mississippi was created using Dufaycolor, an early color-film product. By 2023, it had been transformed by a form of chemical deterioration known as vinegar syndrome. The revolutionary invention of autochromes changed photography. As those pictures decay, they're revealing a new kind of beauty.
In the early 1980s,Â the late National Geographic Society photographer turned archivist Volkmar Wentzel was delving through storage when he stumbled onto something both breathtaking and heartbreaking: a box of delicate glass panels, most of them the size of postcards, displaying color images captured in the early 20th century. Many were deteriorating, their once crisp scenes speckled with ghostly snowflakes, obscured byâ€¦

entry.title: Plan a day in Switzerland's underrated financial capital
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Switzerlandâ€™s largest city, straddling the Limmat River and facing the pristine shores of Lake Zurich, has long been best known for its financial clout and Swiss efficiency. But these days its cultural scene is also booming, with everything from â€˜blackoutâ€™ dining concepts to fashion co-ops set beneath railway arches. Hereâ€™s how best to take in the city in just 14 hours.
The combination of the lakeâ€™s glassy water and this swimming club has made such an impression on locals that itâ€™s kept them rising at dawn for more than 130 years. The Seebadâ€™s two-floor wooden bathhouse debuted in 1890 with curtained changing rooms, ladders directly into the lake and diving boards, and itâ€™s been eulogised ever since by bathers anâ€¦

entry.title: The hunt for the worldâ€™s rarest duck
entry.summary: Known by locals as fotsimaso, or white eye, the Madagascar pochard is a diver. Like other diving ducksâ€”and unlike dabbling ducksâ€”their legs are farther back on their bodies, which helps propel them underwater and makes them appear more upright than dabblers when standing. They are the only ducks in their genus (Aythya) that live almost entirely on invertebrates, with a particular fondness for mothlike caddis flies that breed in the vegetation surrounding lakes. In flight, the critically endangered birds reveal pale bellies and white underwings. The dogged search for a bird that many people figured had gone extinct included torrential rains, washed-out bridges, swine flu, and unrelenting obsession. The Madagascar pochard, compared with other ducks, has little to câ€¦

entry.title: This Sicilian town feeds the worldâ€™s almond craze
The most expensive mistake in ancient Roman history
entry.summary:
The passage is easy to miss.Â A paragraph-long anecdote in theÂ AnnalsÂ by the Roman historian Tacitus, it tells a story found nowhere else, about an unpopular legate forcing legionaries into a treacherous mine at the frontier of the empire. It takes place during the reign of Claudius (A.D. 41â€“54), a time of furious expansion when Rome sought to swallow up the borderlands and their resources. The location mentioned in the Tacitus passage is vague, described as â€œin the district of Mattium,â€ just outside of Roman-occupied Germania Superior. But the goal is clear: to find more of a metal that powered the realm.
Silver trickled down from patricians, officers, and soldiers to the rest of the economy, in the form of coins and ingots and jewelry. Coins were not merely currency. Stamped with theâ€¦

entry.title: Spainâ€™s most decadent foodie town isnâ€™t where you think it is
entry.summary:
People from around the world are traveling to Astorga for its burgeoning food scene. For hikers and walkers, the Spanish city is a lesser-known stop along the famous Camino de Santiago (Saint James Way). Located in the interior of Iberia, this scenic city has mastered the art of savory and sweet with its iconic regional cuisine and centuries-old chocolate industry.
From A CoruÃ±a to Valencia, the Spanish coastline is rife with cities that have earned worldwide acclaim for their food scenes. However, those who venture into the countryâ€™s interior can find a truly rewarding destinationâ€”Astorga. A prominent settlement within the autonomous community of Castilla y LeÃ³n, this scenic city has mastered the art of savory and sweet dishes, providing visitors with an opportunity to sample sugaâ€¦

entry.title: Deadly floods show need for faster, wider warnings, UN agency says
entry.summary: From the Himalayas to rural Texas, deadly floods this month have killed hundreds and exposed dangerous gaps in early warning systems, the UNâ€™s weather agency warned, linking the devastation to rapid urbanization, land-use change and a warming climate that traps more moisture in the atmosphere.

entry.title: People dying from lack of aid every day in Gaza: WFP official
entry.summary: The hunger crisis in Gaza has reached new and astonishing levels of desperation, with a third of the population not eating for multiple days in a row, a senior official with the UN World Food Programme (WFP) said on Monday.

entry.title: Syria: Ongoing violence fuelling mass displacement in Sweida
entry.summary: Ongoing sectarian violence in Sweida, Syria has triggered mass displacement in the area as humanitarians attempt to deliver aid.

entry.title: Gaza: Guterres condemns killing of people seeking food as humanitarian conditions deteriorate
entry.summary: UN Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres is appalled by the accelerating breakdown of humanitarian conditions in Gaza, where the last lifelines keeping people alive are collapsing, his Spokesperson said on Monday.

entry.title: Dreams amid the rubble: Gazaâ€™s women speak of homes, loss and hungry children
entry.summary: Hadriya collapses from hunger, Khadija dreams of her kitchen and Hiyam longs for her daughtersâ€™ laughter in the garden â€“ these are the stories of three women from Gaza who embody the daily struggles of mothers exhausted by war, hunger and displacement as the nearly two-year-long conflict continues.

entry.title: Salvaging SDGs still possible, but countries must act now: Guterres
entry.summary: Citing new global agreements on pandemic preparedness, ocean protection and development financing, UN Secretaryâ€‘General AntÃ³nio Guterres said on Monday that recent â€œsigns of momentumâ€ show multilateralism can still deliver.

entry.title: Droughts are causing record devastation worldwide, UN-backed report reveals
entry.summary: Worldwide, some of the most widespread and damaging drought events in recorded history have occurred in recent years due to climate change and resource depletion.

entry.title: How They Did It: Investigating Migrant Abuses on Cargo Truck Smuggling Routes
entry.summary: Tips from four reporters who took part in a seven month-long collaborative investigation into the growing use of cargo trucks to transport migrants and asylum seekers through Mexico.

entry.title: Doha agreement brings DR Congo government and M23 rebels a step closer to peace
entry.summary: An agreement signed by the Government of the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) and the Congo River Alliance/March 23 Movement (AFC/M23) has been hailed by the UN peacekeeping mission in the country (MONUSCO) as â€œan important step towards sustainable peace.â€

entry.title: A practical guide to long-distance walking in the UK
entry.summary:
There are now 16 official National Trails extending across the length and breadth of England and Wales. There is tremendous fun to be had striding across dale and over fell, up mountain gradient and along the precipice of a wildflower-capped sea cliff, but with so many designated walks to choose from, what should you know before setting off?
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Long-distance rambling in Britain is part ofÂ aÂ correspondingly long tradition. In fact, few nationalities enjoy it quite as much as the British: from the South West Coast Path at Landâ€™s End in Cornwall, to the Cape Wrath Trail in the Scottish Highlands, you'll always find a Brit in an anorak. In 1965, the Pennine Way became the first of the UK's National Trails, and now â€” 6â€¦

entry.title: Desks become beds as Haitian school shelters people displaced by violence
entry.summary: Gang violence in Haiti has displaced hundreds of thousands of people and many are finding shelter in former schools where belief in the power of education remains strong.

entry.title: This hidden Italian town is perfect for a summer escape
entry.summary:
Evade the summer holiday crowds along Italy's most popular coastlines and head to Basilicata instead. Known as the â€˜Pearl of the Tyrrhenianâ€™, this little-known stretch of Basilicata goes all out on natural beauty and southern Italian charm. Here's how to spend a leisurely weekend in Maratea.
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
Imagine if the Amalfi Coast was all but unknown â€” thatâ€™s the charm of Maratea. Bordered by Campania to the north and Calabria to the south, the municipality occupies the only portion of the Tyrrhenian coast in the whole of Basilicata. Itâ€™s a near 20-mile stretch home to striking black-sand beaches, boat-fresh seafood and panoramic vistas overlooking the glittering Gulf of Policastro. But despite possessing all the hallmarksâ€¦

entry.title: Who was Nelson Mandela?
entry.summary:
Former South African president and civil rights advocate Nelson Mandela dedicated his life to fighting for equalityâ€”and ultimately helped topple South Africa's racist system of apartheid. His accomplishments are now celebrated each year on July 18, Nelson Mandela International Day.

This activist dedicated his life to dismantling racismâ€”and went from being the worldâ€™s most famous political prisoner to South Africaâ€™s first Black president. Nelson Mandela was born on July 18, 1918, in what was then known as the Union of South Africa, a dominion of the British Empire. Although the majority of the countryâ€™s inhabitants were Black, they were dominated by a white minority population that controlled the land, the wealth, and the governmentâ€”a discriminatory social structure thaâ€¦

entry.title: My best summers were spent at Grand Canyon Lodgeâ€”now itâ€™s gone
entry.summary:
Iâ€™m not usually one to get weepy over a hotel, let alone a patio and some rough-hewn wooden furniture. But when Arizonaâ€™s famous Grand Canyon Lodge and a number of smaller adjacent structures burned down on the night of July 12 in the Dragon Bravo Fire, a blaze that to date has consumed 11,344 acres and remains entirely uncontained, it left a hole in more than just the conifer forest of the North Rim. My heart, my friendsâ€™ heartsâ€”thereâ€™s a hole in each of these now. And there are similar holes in the hearts of thousands of folks across the globe who also loved, and still love, and will forever love, that rustic palace, that gobsmacking view, that superlative place.
In 2024, close to five million visitors experienced the beauty and wonder of Grand Canyon National Park, but only ten perâ€¦

entry.title: See 100 years of New York City
entry.summary:
In the summer of 1957, a replica of the Mayflower sailed into New York Harbor. Dubbed the Mayflower II, it had just finished retracing the Pilgrimsâ€™ 1620 journey across the Atlantic to establish a colony in America. New York City celebrated its arrival with a ticker-tape parade.
That November, National Geographic published an article written by the shipâ€™s captain about the Mayflower IIâ€™s voyage, full of photos of its ocean journey and a victorious arrival in New York City (which was not a stop on the original shipâ€™s route to Plymouth, Massachusetts).
As the city this year celebrates the 400th anniversary of its founding as the Dutch outpost New Amsterdam, National Geographic looked back on its coverage of the city over the last century.
An early article highlighted its drawsâ€¦

entry.title: Felix Baumgartner, famed pilot and BASE jumper, dies at 56
entry.summary:
Felix Baumgartner, the world-renowned Austrian pilot who was named National Geographicâ€™s 2013Â Peopleâ€™s Choice Adventurer of the YearÂ for his fearless aerial feats, has died in Italy.Â
According to local mediaÂ reports, the pilot died after crashing into a hotel pool while paragliding on the Adriatic coast, injuring another person in the accident.
National Geographic has reached out to Baumgartnerâ€™s representatives.
According to the Associated Press, the cityâ€™s mayor confirmed Baumgartnerâ€™s death in a social media post.
â€œOur community is deeply affected by the tragic disappearance of Felix Baumgartner, a figure of global prominence, a symbol of courage and passion for extreme flight,â€ Mayor Massimiliano Ciarpella said.Â
Baumgartner leaves behind a soaring legacy, setâ€¦

entry.title: This underdiagnosed vein disorder affects 4 in 10 Americans
entry.summary:
A nurse practitioner examines a patient with chronic venous insufficiency (CVI), a vascular condition in which damaged leg veins impair blood flow back to the heart. CVI can lead to symptoms such as swelling, skin changes, and venous ulcers if left untreated. From tingly legs to bulging veins, these warning signs may point to chronic venous insufficiencyâ€”a widespread circulatory issue doctors say is on the rise.
Swelling, aching calves, tingling, or bulging veins might seem like everyday discomforts, but they could point to a hidden problem in your circulatory system. A surprisingly common yet underrecognized condition called chronic venous insufficiency is behind a growing number of casesâ€”and scientists say itâ€™s far more widespread than most people realize.
Here are five thinâ€¦

entry.title: Wellness is going high tech at these hotels
entry.summary:
In addition to massages and facials, hotel spas are adding in space-age wellness treatments to their services. All-natural treatments like aromatherapy and mud facials used to be all the rage. But now, top hotels around the world are offering something decidedly different.
Natural treatments and products have long been wellness buzzwordsâ€”think of aromatherapy sessions using plant-derived ingredients, or skin-smoothing immersions in mineral-rich volcanic mud. But now, a different approach is on the rise.
â€œWhatâ€™s becoming more common is a model where everything is scientifically calibrated,â€ says Amy Larocca, author of the recent book How to Be Well: Navigating Our Self-Care Epidemic, One Dubious Cure at a Time, a skepticâ€™s take on wellness culture in the United States.
On â€¦

entry.title: What do you do with thousands of dead Everglades pythons?
entry.summary: Just after midnight, Elle Barbeito drove her Dodge pickup deep into the shadows of the Florida Everglades. After hours navigating narrow marsh roads, past towering bald cypresses and raucous shoots of bromeliads, she suddenly pulled onto the shoulder and aimed a flashlight at a writhing patch of prehistoric-looking ferns. â€œPython!â€ Barbeito shouted, pointing to a metallic sheen of scales glistening like silken chain mail in the moonlight. The next part would require her gun.Â https://interactives.natgeofe.com/high-touch/ngm-2507-Python-Fashion-Map/builds/main/html/_graphic.html No one can say for certain how Burmese pythons arrived in the Everglades in the first place or how many there are today, though conservative estimates put their population in the tens of thousands. What weâ€¦

entry.title: World News in Brief: Violence in Haiti, rising insecurity in DR Congo, expert panel on nuclear war
entry.summary: The UN humanitarian affairs office OCHA is stressing the need to scale up support for displaced families in Haiti amid ongoing insecurity and violence.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Humanitarians report more deaths, displacement and desperation in Gaza
entry.summary: The continued onslaught and mass deprivation of people in the Gaza Strip is becoming normalised, the UN aid coordination office OCHA warned on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN80 initiative should be â€˜inclusive and transparentâ€™, recognises General Assembly
entry.summary: The General Assembly on Friday adopted by consensus a resolution on the Secretaryâ€‘Generalâ€™s UN80 Initiative to strengthen and streamline the United Nations system.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Mandelaâ€™s legacy â€˜is now our responsibilityâ€™, Guterres says on International Day
entry.summary: In honour of Nelson Mandela International Day on Friday, the United Nations is celebrating with a public service activity, a chamber music concert and a General Assembly meeting, where Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres presented the 2025 Mandela Prize.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN envoy urges Colombia to â€˜stay the courseâ€™ as peace faces new strains
entry.summary: Colombia has changed profoundly since the 2016 peace deal, but uneven state presence, lingering armed groups and mounting political tensions threaten to erode confidence unless implementation accelerates, the top UN envoy for the country said on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜You have to be able to rule your lifeâ€™: The care revolution in Latin America
entry.summary: Globally, there are 12.5 billion hours of work that the world never pays for because it barely even sees these duties.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: On the road in war-torn Gaza
entry.summary: Mohammed Saad sits with others inside a homemade cart pulled by a car carrying several passengers, waiting to travel to Gaza City in one of the â€œuncomfortable and extremely expensiveâ€ means of transportation used to get around the Strip.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Aid cuts leave refugee agency unable to shelter six in 10 fleeing war in Sudan
entry.summary: Major cuts to aid budgets have already left people fleeing wars in Sudan and beyond without the assistance and protection they need, the UN refugee agency, UNHCR,Â said on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Syria crisis: Hundreds killed in ongoing violence, hospitals overwhelmed
entry.summary: Amid violent clashes in southern Syriaâ€™s Sweida governorate, a picture of grave human rights abuses and rising humanitarian needs is emerging by the hour, the UN said on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: As war rages on in Ukraine, organised crime is taking new forms
entry.summary: Almost four years after Russiaâ€™s full-scale invasion, criminal groups in Ukraine are adapting their business models amid displacement, rising trafficking risks and an increased demand for synthetic drugs, the UN Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC) said in a report published on Friday.

entry.title: The best place to snorkle with whale sharks? It's in Australia
entry.summary:
Whale sharks, humpbacks, southern right whales, orcas, mighty mantas, turtles and some 700 species of fish await just offshore, often within paddling distance of the beachâ€™s windblown dunes. Whale sharks, coral reefs and safari tents amid the dunes: this remote lodge immerses travellers in Western Australiaâ€™s astounding marine world.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The Ningaloo Coast is where outback, reef and ranges meet. Here, on the northwestern fringes of Australia, 745 miles above Perth on a rocky thumb of a promontory that juts into the Indian Ocean, great ochre canyons and stretches of flat, red earth slip into water thatâ€™s as bright blue as a kingfisher. This is also where marine giants meet â€” among them whale sharks, humpbacks, southâ€¦

entry.title: Tornadoes, explained
entry.summary:
Tornadoes are vertical funnels of rapidly spinning air. Their winds may top 250 miles an hour and can clear a pathway a mile wide and 50 miles long.
Twisters are born in thunderstorms and are often accompanied by hail. Giant, persistent thunderstorms called supercells spawn the most destructive.
These violent storms occur around the world, but the United States is a major hotspot, with the number of tornadoes clocking in at about 1,200 per year.
â€œTornado Alley,â€ a region that includes the area in the eastern state of South Dakota, Nebraska, Kansas, Oklahoma, northern Texas, and eastern Colorado, is often home to the most powerful and destructive of these storms. U.S. tornadoes cause 80 deaths and more than 1,500 injuries per year, according to the National Weather Service. â€¦

entry.title: A photographer's guide to Texas
entry.summary:
From the geological wonders of Big Bend National Park to the scenic coastlines of Corpus Christi, Texas is a land of infinite varietyâ€”and endless photographic inspiration. On assignment, National Geographic photographer Tara Kerzhner set out to capture the spirit and soul of the Lone Star State through its dramatic landscapes, local characters, and hidden corners. What she found was a place full of adventures and breathtaking beauty at every turn.
Here, she shares some of her favorite images and the moments behind them. undefined undefined undefined undefined undefined undefined undefined undefined undefined undefined

entry.title: A coastal adventure along the Texas Gulf
entry.summary:
Thereâ€™s a certain magic to the Texas Gulf Coastâ€”especially in and around Corpus Christiâ€”where the warm sea breeze carries the scent of salt and adventure. Itâ€™s a place that feels both untamed and inviting, where coastal experiences unfold at every turn. Whether youâ€™re watching migratory birds soar overhead, riding horseback along the shoreline on Mustang Island, savoring freshly caught Gulf seafood at a dockside eatery, or sailing into a blazing sunset on Corpus Christi Bay, each moment draws you deeper into the rhythm of life by the sea.
Discover the natural beauty and coastal charm of the Texas Gulf Coastâ€”one photo at a time. undefined undefined undefined undefined undefined undefined undefined undefined undefined undefined

entry.title: Photo story: Exploring the rugged beauty of Big Bend, Texas
entry.summary:
Big skies. Bigger adventures. Welcome to Big Bendâ€”West Texasâ€™ untamed trifecta of mountains, river valleys, and desert landscapes. Itâ€™s a place that feels raw and remote, yet deeply soulful, where every trail, canyon, and star-filled sky invites exploration. Whether youâ€™re hiking through the dramatic peaks of the Chisos Mountains, paddling the Rio Grande through ancient limestone canyons, or simply watching the landscape come alive at golden hour, every moment here connects you to something wild and timeless.
Experience the rugged beauty and enduring spirit of Big Bendâ€”one photo at a time. undefined undefined undefined undefined undefined undefined undefined undefined

entry.title: Photo story: A window into West Texas culture
entry.summary:
Where vast horizons meet dynamic expression, West Texas unfolds as a canvas of culture, history, and creativity. From the striking art installations of Marfa to the historic charm of Alpine and Marathon, this region pulses with a unique spirit that blends frontier grit with cultural innovation. Whether youâ€™re exploring outdoor galleries or staying in one-of-a-kind accommodations, West Texas invites you to discover a world where art, culture, and heritage come alive against a backdrop of sweeping vistas and endless skies.
Experience the spirit and soul of West Texasâ€”one frame at a time.
Roll Gate (2022) by Charles Harlan features a single roll-down gateâ€”typically used to secure storefrontsâ€”reimagined as a freestanding sculpture. Golden-hour light casts a visitorâ€™s shadow across adobe-style structures in Marfa. Sam Falls' installation Life in California (2023) features a red truck transformed by the elements and time. Visible in the background is Matt Johnson's Sleeping Figure (2023).Â Each installation invites a different view of the West Texas landscape.
undefined undefined

entry.title: What is methylene blue and can it really boost your brain power?
entry.summary:
A solution of methylene blue in an erlenmeyer flask. The trending dye was invented by German chemist Heinrich Caro in 1876. The trendy supplement was originally developed as a fabric dyeâ€”and later used as a malaria treatment. We asked experts if it really has the cognitive benefits touted on social media.
If youâ€™ve spotted someone recently with a blue tongue, that inky stain could actually be the side effect of a new health trend.
Biohacking enthusiasts have been using a substance calledÂ methylene blueÂ as a daily supplement, sharing videos of their stained tongues on TikTok. Users claim the highly pigmented compound, which was originally developed as a fabric dye before being used for medical purposes, can improveÂ cognitive function,Â energy levelsÂ andÂ mood, and could even prevâ€¦

entry.title: Skeleton reveals that some ancient women were extreme hermits
entry.summary:
Today the most extreme forms of devotion to God in Christianity involve tithing, abstaining from meat on Fridays and during Lent, taking religious orders and devoting oneself to a life of celibacy, and, perhaps, taking vows of poverty or even silence.
All of these practices pale next to the forms of asceticism practiced in the Byzantine period, when the most dedicated monks isolated themselves from human contact in the desert, restricted their food and sleep, wrapped themselves in uncomfortable sore-inducing chains, and lived their lives on top of small pillars.
Traditionally, the most hardcore ascetics were believed to have been men, but recent scholarly and archeological research has revealed that female monastics were equally devoted to self-mortification.
In 1924, excavaâ€¦

entry.title: Blowing out birthday candles is surprisingly ancient
entry.summary:
If youâ€™ve been to a birthday party, youâ€™ve probably seen it: the cake comes out, the candles are lit, the room sings, and the birthday person makes a wish before blowing them out. Itâ€™s a moment we donâ€™t think twice aboutâ€”but it didnâ€™t start as just a party tradition.
From moonlit offerings in ancient Greece to protective spells in medieval Germany, birthday candles were once used to invoke blessings, ward off misfortune, and represent the delicate balance between life and death.
So, how did a spiritual ritual evolve into a party trick? Hereâ€™s how cultures around the world have used fire, food, and celebration to mark the passage of time.
The history of birthday candles
While itâ€™s commonly said that the tradition of birthday candles began in ancient Greece, thereâ€™s no diâ€¦

entry.title: Scientists record a black hole collision they werenâ€™t sure was possible
Scientists are racing to develop a â€˜living computerâ€™
entry.summary:
Scientists are experimenting with ways to integrate brain cells into computer processors. The technology could help conserve energy. FinalSpark's Multi-Electrode Arrays (MEAs) incorporate four human brain organoids, each interfacing with eight electrodes. The potential for these kinds of machines to reshape computer processing, increase energy efficiency, and revolutionize medical testing has scientists excited. But when do we consider these cells to be conscious?
In 2022, a group of Australian researchers ran a rudimentary simulation of the arcade game, Pong. None of them were controlling the virtual paddle, and yet, after a few misses, the paddle moved up and down the screen on its own to meet the returning ball and hit it back.
The 2D game was wired to a cluster of lab-groâ€¦

entry.title: This untamed island is the Caribbeanâ€™s best-kept secret
entry.summary:
Mount Scenery, a dormant volcano, is the highest point in the Kingdom of the Netherlands. There are no traffic lights, no high-rises, no beaches, and no crowds on tiny Saba. Instead, youâ€™ll find misty mountains, epic hikes, and vibrant reefs.
Located 28 miles from St. Maarten, the five-square-mile island of Saba isnâ€™t the first place that springs to mind when it comes to adventure travel. Draped in wild greenery from every angle, this volcanic island looks almost vacant from afar. With no traffic lights, no high-rises, no beaches, and no crowds, it remains relatively under the radar as one of the smallest inhabited islands in the Caribbean.Â
However, that same remoteness is exactly what once made Saba both uninviting and intriguing. In 1493, the island caught the eye of Christâ€¦

entry.title: Hereâ€™s why stargazers are flocking to the Oregon Outback
entry.summary:
DarkSky International has designated more than 2.4 million acres in Southeast Oregon, including Lake County, as a dark sky sanctuary, making it the largest in the world. The largest dark sky sanctuary in the world is 2.4 million acres of volcanic landscape, deserts, and mountains. Learn how to plan your trip.
Southeast OregonÂ is a patchwork of high desert, mountains, and volcanic landscape, stitched together by river canyons and long stretches of solitude.Â When darkness falls on clear nightsÂ across this region, visitors can watch a shimmering blanket of stars emerge.Â
In March 2024, The 2.4-million-acre Oregon OutbackÂ officially becameÂ the largest dark sky sanctuaryÂ in the world.Â DarkSky International, an organization dedicated to preserving dark places to mitigate the harmfulâ€¦

entry.title: How magnesium affects your sleep and anxiety
entry.summary: Magnesium is an important mineral that can help with muscle soreness, migraines, blood pressure, osteoporosis, and potentially even lower the risks of bone fractures, heart disease, type 2 diabetes, and stroke. But experts say it's not clear everyone needs to take supplementsâ€”nor that it really helps with sleep and anxiety as many have claimed on social media. The essential mineral is important for the bodyâ€”but it doesnâ€™t work miracles. Hereâ€™s wâ€¦
