entry.title: US tariff delay deepens trade uncertainty, warns top UN economist
entry.summary: A leading UN trade official warned on Tuesday that the United Statesâ€™ decision to delay the end of a tariff suspension by a few weeks risks prolonging global uncertainty and undermining long-term investments and commercial contracts.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: In South Asia, anaemia threatens womenâ€™s health and economic futures
entry.summary: Anaemia remains one of South Asiaâ€™s quietest but most pervasive health crises, disproportionately affecting the regionâ€™s poorest women and girls â€“ and with 18 million more cases projected by 2030, experts say urgent, unified action is critical.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Ukraine: UN refugee agency helps repair homes amid ongoing conflict
entry.summary: As relentless attacks continue to damage homes and communities across Ukraine, the UN refugee agency (UNHCR) has now helped repair over 40,000 war-damaged homes â€“ marking a major step in helping displaced families return and recover.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: South Sudanâ€™s longest cholera outbreak enters critical stage
entry.summary: On the eve of the fourteenth anniversary of its independence, South Sudan â€“ the worldâ€™s youngest country â€“ is experiencing its worst and longest cholera outbreak.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: Hospitals rationing critical supplies, ambulances stalling
entry.summary: UN humanitarians have warned that the catastrophic conditions in Gaza are worsening, as tents, schools, homes and medical facilities come under attack, and fuel supplies run out.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN summit confronts AIâ€™s dawn of wonders and warnings
entry.summary: The UNâ€™s flagship platform on artificial intelligence opened in Geneva on Tuesday, launching four days of high-level dialogue, cutting-edge demonstrations and urgent calls for inclusive AI governance. The event comes as autonomous and generative systems evolve faster than regulatory frameworks can keep pace.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Srebrenica, 30 years on: UN officials and survivors call for truth, justice and vigilance
entry.summary: At the UN General Assembly on Tuesday, survivors of the Srebrenica genocide joined top officials in marking 30 years since thousands of Bosnian Muslims were systematically killed in the worst atrocity on European soil since World War II. The affirmed the need to counter denial, support survivors and promote lasting peace.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN rights office urges restraint in Kenya as fresh protests turn deadly
entry.summary: The UN human rights office, OHCHR, has expressed deep concern over the killing of at least ten protesters in Kenya on Monday, amid reports that police and security forces used lethal force to quell violent demonstrations in Nairobi and across the country.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: On this Indonesian island, tempeh is king
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
â€œTempeh brownies,â€ chef Froosh Nur announces as he places a plate down in front of me.
Iâ€™m not sure how this is going to work. Iâ€™ve never tried tempeh in sweet form before, but these donâ€™t look any different to normal brownies, and as I sink my teeth in, a familiar chocolatey taste emerges. The texture is perfectly moist and gooey; a delicate crunch comes not from nuts, but from the soybeans in the tempeh.
Originally from Kerala in Southern India, Froosh moved to the Indonesian island of Lombok last year to take up the position of head chef at The Sira, one of the many high-end resorts that line the palm-fringed turquoise coast in the islandâ€™s quieter northwest corner, between the Bali Sea and the imposing sloâ€¦

entry.title: Aging isnâ€™t all bad. Hereâ€™s how health improves as we grow older.
entry.summary:
While aging is often framed negatively, researchers have uncovered surprising benefits. Above, members of a senior synchronized swimming team pose during practice. New science suggests there's plenty that actually gets better with ageâ€”if you let it.
We spend billions of dollars each year trying to fight agingâ€”covering up wrinkles, dyeing gray hair, and chasing the promise of youth. However, while aging is often portrayed as a slow decline, scientists say that view overlooks the bigger picture. â€œEveryone talks about aging as this decline,â€ says Michelle Feng, chief clinical officer at Executive Mental Health and a licensed psychologist who specializes in geriatric psychology and medicine. â€œBut aging is just living. It literally means that youâ€™re alive.â€
How you choose to think â€¦

entry.title: The 17,000th species to enter Nat Geo's Photo Ark
entry.summary:
Birds-of-paradise have captivated the planet with their elaborate plumage and idiosyncratic mating dances. Some species appear to shape-shift as they elongate plumes of feathers, fan their wings, or even hang upside down from a tree branch like a bat.
There are about 40 species in the birds-of-paradise family, and all are native to either Papua New Guinea, its surrounding islands, or Australia.
â€œTheyâ€™re like no other birds on earth,â€Â says Joel Sartore,Â National Geographic Explorer, photographer, and creator ofÂ Photo Ark.Â
Since 2006, Sartore has been traveling the globe in a bid to document as many species as humanly possible. And as of this writing, he has approached a number that once seemed unthinkableâ€”17,000 species lovingly coaxed into posing for his camera. Usually, Saâ€¦

author.name: Joel Sartore/National Geographic Photo Ark, Jason Bittel

entry.title: How mournful fado music offers a window into Lisbon's soul
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Itâ€™s nearing midnight in Alfama, Lisbonâ€™s oldest neighbourhood, when a lady in black steps into a taverna.
The bar staff scurry to turn off the lights, leaving only the flickering tapers of candles to illuminate her angular features and fringed shawl, which sheâ€™s pulled tight around her shoulders. Elvira Giblott scans the room, as if reaching for a muse, then greets the two guitarists by the bar with the title of a song. In the restaurant, every fork is stilled, every wine glass untouched. She sings of Lisbon, of the beauty and struggle of life here, her voice filling the room before dropping to a velvety whisper. Itâ€™s as if her heart is breaking before our eyes.
When, several songs later, the seasoned singerâ€¦

entry.title: Can we diagnose Alzheimerâ€™s earlier than we think?
entry.summary: The accumulation of neurofibrillary tanglesâ€”like those illustrated here inside a neuronâ€”is closely associated with cognitive decline caused by Alzheimerâ€™s disease. A recent study found that several biomarkers implicated in Alzheimerâ€™s are associated with cognitive decline as early as ages 24 to 44. Treating the neurodegenerative disease in its earlier stages is key to slowing cognitive decline. A new study offers hope for the future. More than a century ago, a German neuroanatomist noticed his patient acting inordinately confused. After she died, Alois Alzheimer examined her brain and discovered amyloid-beta plaques and neurofibrillary â€œtanglesâ€¦

entry.title: How flash floods get so destructive so quickly
'Ash-winged dawn goddess' pterosaur just discovered
entry.summary:
Paleontologists searching the ancient rock of Petrified Forest National Park, Arizona, have uncovered an exceptional bonebed. Dating to 209 million years ago, the Triassic trove includes nearly 1,500 fossils from fish, frogs, turtles, crocodile-like predators, and more. Most remarkable of all, it yielded fossilized remains from the oldest pterosaur yet found in North America: Eotephradactylus mcintireae, or the â€œash-winged dawn goddess.â€
Early pterosaurs are notoriously difficult to find. The flying reptiles took to the air thanks to leathery wings of skin stretched between their bodies and an extremely elongated fourth finger. Their small size and hollow bones made flight easier but also meant their skeletons were often destroyed before fossilization could occur. The discovery of a jâ€¦

entry.title: Where to experience Black culture in Paris
entry.summary:
Travelers searching for immersive Black or African cultural experiences in Paris can start with a stroll through MarchÃ© Dejean in the cityâ€™s La Goutte dâ€™Or district, also known as Little Africa. From Little Africa to the jazz cafes where Josephine Baker performed, hereâ€™s where to immerse yourself in the art, food, and culture of Parisâ€™s African diaspora.
Creative Black minds and artisans have been present inÂ Parisâ€™s renowned art and food scene since the 1920s. American writers like Langston Hughes and James Baldwin found a home in the cityâ€™s bustling jazz cafes, and their future works have laid the foundation for Black American literature.Â Â In addition to literary legends, tens of thousands of families of African origin reside in Paris, specifically in the 18th arrondissement, wherâ€¦

entry.title: A witch-free guide to Salem, Massachusetts
entry.summary:
Salem, Massachusetts, is renowned for its witch trials, but this charming New England town has so much more to offer. The infamous witch trials may have put this Boston suburb on the map, but theyâ€™ve also overshadowed much of its magic. Hereâ€™s how to experience everything else Salem has to offer.
When 19 people were hung for witchcraft in Salem, Massachusetts, between February 1692 and May 1693, they sealed the cityâ€™s identity forever as â€œthe Witch City.â€ Thatâ€™s reinforced daily by Salem itselfâ€”in the names of shops, museums, restaurants, boutiques, and school teams. Add to this neighborhoods dense with
Colonial-era homes fit for a Crucible film set, especially when the ocean fog rolls in. But nothing certifies the witch logo more than the million-plus tourists that flood Saleâ€¦
